title_sort: walt whitman to ellen m. o'connor, 25 september 1890
title: Walt Whitman to Ellen M. O'Connor, 25 September 1890
text: Sept. 25, 1890—BCamden New JerseySept. 25 1890My dear friend,Here is the Preface—three printed slips, copies—not so much of preface to the tales, but my memorial & reminiscence of dear W—& to give a dash of appropriate & something (I hardly can say what but I think I know) different or varied to the book.—How are you getting along?—I often think ab't you & Wm & old times—& you & y'r fortunes present, tapering off the rest. I am here in the same spot & in not much different conditions—good spirits enough (constitutional I guess, physiological likely)—but almost a complete bodily wreck, cannot get across the room without holding on to something, or being led—have a stout man nurse—go out-doors in wheel chair occasionally was out yesterday at sunset—sell my own books when I can get purchaser—am still rejected by all the magazines—my right arm power & volition good yet—appetite, sleep &c: fair—am now well on my 72d year—have the grip rather bad—cool spell of weather here—Dr Bucke is well—Horace Traubel comes dailyGod bless youWalt Whitman Walt Whitman to Ellen M. O'Connor, 25 September 1890
